title: Fagus orientalis
text:
Fagus orientalis, commonly known as the Oriental beech, is a <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="tree">tree</a> in the <a href="beech">beech</a> family <a href="Fagaceae">Fagaceae</a>. It is native to <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>, in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a> and <a href="Western%20Asia">Western Asia</a>.
Description.
"Fagus orientalis" is a large tree, capable of reaching heights of up to tall and trunk diameter, though more typically tall and up to trunk diameter.
The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are alternate, simple, and entire or with a slightly crenate margin, long and broad, with 7–13 veins on each side of the leaf (6–7 veins in "F. sylvatica"). The <a href="bud">bud</a>s are long and slender, long and thick, but thicker, till , where the buds include flower buds.
The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are small <a href="catkin">catkin</a>s which appear shortly after the leaves in spring.
The <a href="seed">seed</a>s are small triangular <a href="Nut%20%28fruit%29">nuts</a> long and wide at the base; there are two nuts in each cupule, maturing in the autumn 5–6 months after pollination. The cupule differs from that of European Beech in having flattened, slightly leaf-like appendages at the base (slender, soft spines in European Beech).
Taxonomy.
"Fagus orientalis" is closely related to the <a href="Fagus%20sylvatica">"Fagus sylvatica" (European Beech)</a>, and intergrades with it in the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a> and northwestern Turkey. These <a href="Hybrid%20%28biology%29">hybrids</a> with European Beech are named "Fagus × taurica".
Distribution and habitat.
The tree's natural range extends from southeastern Bulgaria's <a href="Strandja">Strandja</a> mountain, through northwest <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, and east to the <a href="Caucasus%20Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a> in <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a> and Russia, to the <a href="Alborz%20Mountains">Alborz Mountains</a> in <a href="Iran">Iran</a>.
Its habitat is restricted to <a href="mountain">mountain</a> forests, at of altitude.
The Oriental beech has colonized even lower altitudes in the <a href="Strandja">Strandja</a> mountain of <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> as low as above sea-level, due to the unique local micro-climate, where it forms typical "Fagus orientalis"−"<a href="Rhododendron%20ponticum">Rhododendron ponticum</a>" forests as well as with other evergreen shrubs.
Use.
The wood of "Fagus orientalis" is heavy, hard, strong and highly resistant to shock. These features makes it suitable for <a href="steam%20bending">steam bending</a>. The wood is also a source to <a href="fuelwood">fuelwood</a> and can be used for constructions <a href="particleboard">particleboard</a>, furniture, flooring <a href="Wood%20veneer">veneer</a>, mining poles, railway tiles and paper.
